questions.text: Which of the following antihypertensive drug reduces proteinuria in a diabetic patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Perindopril

Highyeild:

ACE inhibitors like Perindopril reduces proteinuria in a diabetic patient, so ACE inhibitors are preferred in diabetic hypertensives Prolonged ACE inhibi¬¬tor therapy has been found to prevent or delay end-stage renal disease in type I as well as type II diabetics. Albuminuria (an index of glomerulopathy) remains stable in those treated with ACE inhibitor, but aggravates in untreated diabetics. Treated patients have higher creatinine clearance, require less dialysis and have longer life expectancy. Benefits appear to be due to haemodynamic (systemic and intrarenal) as well as abnormal mesangial cell growth attenuating effects of ACE inhibitors. They reduce intraglomerular pressure and hyperfiltration.

questions.text: Cough and angioedema in a patient receiving ACE inhibitors is due to:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bradykinin

Highyeild:

Cough and angioedema in a patient receving ACE inhibitors is due to Bradykinin. Bradykinin is broken down by enzyme ACE. So, inhibition of ACE leads to high levels of Bradykinin leading to Cough and angioedema A persistent brassy cough occurs in 10–16% patients within 1–8 weeks, often requires discontinuation of the drug—subsides 4–6 days thereafter. It is not dose related and appears to be caused by inhibition of bradykinin/substance P breakdown in the lungs of susceptible individuals.

questions.text: 56-year-old patient with essential hypertension on ACE inhibitors for 6 months develops chronic refractory dry cough. What would be the correct action to be taken?

options.label: A
options.text: Reduce the dose of ACE inhibitor

options.label: D
options.text: Order for a CT scan of chest

questions.correct_answer: C. Change to Angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB)
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Change to Angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB)

Highyeild:

Reduce the dose of ACE inhibitor: Reducing the dose will not help as the patient is already sensitized to the adverse effects To add anti-tussives: Adding anti tussives will not help, as the cause for cough is ACE inhibitors Change to Angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB) The best next option is to shift to ARB for hypertension control. Arbs are not known to cause dry cough, as they will not inhibit degradation of bradykinin, substance P, and/or prostaglandins. Order for a CT scan of chest Ordering a CT chest is not helpful as the cause of cough is known and it burdens the patient with additional cost

questions.text: Angiotensin receptor blocker which blocks thromboxane A2:
